answers: It looks like the honeymoon is over between Trump and Obama. "Doing my best to disregard the many inflammatory President O statements and roadblocks. Thought it was going to be a smooth transition—NOT!" Trump tweeted Wednesday. The Los Angeles Times notes Trump's use of "1990s-style sarcasm." Trump had previously commended Obama on his commitment to a smooth transition of power, but a number of things have changed since then, the Washington Post reports. Many saw comments made by Obama during Tuesday's Pearl Harbor anniversary as directed at Trump. The president urged the US not to "turn inward" and to "resist the urge to demonize those who are different." Trump is also upset with the Obama administration for allowing the UN to pass a resolution condemning Israeli settlements, as well as with Obama personally for saying in an interview he could have beaten Trump and won a third term. In addition, the White House is defending the Department of Energy for not complying with a request from Trump's transition team for the names of employees involved in climate policy, ABC News reports. Transition team spokesperson Sean Spicer at first said Trump's tweets "speak for themselves, very clearly," but later complimented members of the Obama administration for being "helpful and generous with their time."

pred: In two separate news articles, a Chinese man named Guan Quanzhi has received compensation for an attack by a wild panda in Gansu Province, China. The incident occurred in March 2014 when a wild panda chased by other villagers ran onto Guan's land while he was working on his farmland. The panda bit Guan in the leg, causing him to undergo eight surgeries over the past year. Guan sued three government departments responsible for controlling wild animals, including the forestry bureau at the provincial level and of Longnan city, and the management bureau of Baishuijiang Natural Reserve. The forestry bureau agreed to pay Guan 520,000 yuan ($83,000) in compensation, while the management bureau of Baishuijiang Natural Reserve agreed to pay an additional 200,000 yuan ($32,000). Guan is satisfied with the amount, which will cover his medical bills, and he may need further operations. The incident highlights the challenges faced by wildlife conservationists in protecting these endangered animals, particularly in areas where they are often targeted by poachers or other human activities. Despite their adorable appearance, wild pandas are members of the bear family and possess powerful jaws and teeth, making them potential threats to humans. Conservation efforts, such as habitat protection and anti-poaching measures, are crucial to ensuring the survival of these magnificent creatures.
answers: Pandas may prefer their meals in the form of bamboo, but that doesn't mean their bite is toothless. A man in China recently received a harsh reminder of that after a wild panda bit his leg after authorities pursued the critter onto his lawn, reports AFP via Yahoo. The creature had made its way into a northwestern village, which is near a sanctuary that's home to about 100 wild pandas. "I saw a panda jump out in front of me, its body completely covered in mud," the man told local news. A struggle ensued, in which the bear wouldn't release the man's leg until a rescuer wrapped a coat around the animal's head. Finally, it fled—but not before causing injuries which, China Daily reports, led to eight surgeries over the past year and may lead to amputation. The man sued three government departments and won an $83,000 payout that will cover his medical costs, his lawyer says. (China Daily has a pretty gruesome photo of the injury.) "As cuddly as they may look, a panda can protect itself as well as most other bears," the World Wildlife Fund notes, per AFP. Indeed, panda attacks have led to some nasty consequences in the past.

pred: The Tennessee Bureau of Investigation (TBI) has issued an Amber Alert after a 9-year-old girl named Carlie Trent was reported missing by her uncle, Gary Simpson, on May 4th. The TBI has received reports of Simpson purchasing various items, including a pink and purple "plush throw" blanket, a green men's short-sleeve shirt, men's black pants, girls' khaki pants, two shades of lipstick, two shades of nail polish, a pink folding camp chair, a purple child-sized nightgown, a bikini, and a Fruit of the Loom brand girls' multipack of underwear. Simpson is described as being balding, approximately 5 feet 10 inches tall, and weighing 157 pounds, with brown hair and brown eyes. Both are white. The TBI has launched a massive search effort, involving law enforcement agencies in 19 states, including many in the Southeast, to locate Simpson and Carlie Trent. The agency has sifted through over 1,200 leads and has identified potential sightings in 11 states, including many in the rural areas. The TBI has also reached out to state park officials and private campgrounds in Tennessee, North Carolina, Virginia, and Kentucky, asking for any suspicious activity. The TBI has not yet received a credible sighting, but they remain committed to finding the missing girl and bringing her home safely. The TBI has also released a security video of Simpson taken at a Rogersville-area Walmart shortly before he picked up Carlie from her school, claiming that her father had been in an accident. The TBI has stated that Simpson's purchases suggest he may be in an isolated area, and they are urging property owners in rural areas to take a look around their land for anything suspicious. The TBI has also asked anyone with immediate information on the pair's location to call the TBI at 1-800-824-3463. The TBI has emphasized the importance of trusting them in their search efforts and encourages the public to report any sightings or information that may lead to the safe return of Carlie Trent. The TBI has also released a statement expressing its commitment to protecting the welfare of the girl and ensuring her safety.
answers: Authorities are combing through more than 1,200 leads in a desperate search for a 9-year-old girl they say was abducted by her uncle May 4, WATE reports. According to the Knoxville News Sentinel, 57-year-old Gary Simpson picked Carlie Trent up from her Tennessee school, telling staff her father had been in an accident. Shortly before, he purchased a child's nightgown, bikini, girls' underwear, lipstick, and nail polish at an area Walmart. The Tennessee Bureau of Investigation has pictures of those items. Carlie's mother Shannon Trent tells People she felt "sick to my stomach" when she heard about those purchases. "I don't know what he's done to her," she says. "I don't think he would hurt her, but if he's capable of kidnapping a child he's capable of anything." Authorities believe Carlie is in "imminent danger." Simpson also purchased camping supplies and nonperishable groceries, and authorities think he may be hiding with Carlie in an isolated area. The TBI says there have been rumors online that Simpson is trying to protect Carlie, but it says that couldn't be further from the truth. "This was not an innocent camping trip, this was a crime," a spokesperson tells WATE. Simpson, Carlie's uncle by marriage, and his wife once had custody of Carlie, but her father James Trent had custody at the time of her abduction. Shannon Trent, who hasn't had custody of Carlie in two years, says she "always had a bad feeling" about Simpson. "I should have stuck with my gut," she tells People. (This boy's summer with his dad turned into his kidnapping.)

pred: In a major shake-up, CBS' "The Early Show" has announced the departure of co-hosts Maggie Rodriguez, Harry Smith, and Dave Price, while Chris Wragge and Erica Hill will replace them as co-anchors of the weekday show starting January 3. The new team includes Jeff Glor, who will anchor the network's Saturday newscast, and Marysol Castro, who will serve as a weather anchor. Smith will become the primary substitute anchor for Katie Couric's evening newscast, "Face the Nation" and "Sunday Morning." The decision to replace the show's current lineup comes after a period of uncertainty, with the network facing declining ratings and competition from other morning shows like "Today" and "Good Morning America." The new team is expected to bring fresh energy and chemistry to the show, which has struggled in recent years to maintain its position in the network morning news ratings. However, the impact of the changes remains to be seen, and the network is yet to announce the specific roles for Rodriguez and Price. The new team will begin on January 3, and there is no immediate expectation of significant ratings changes due to the shift in focus from hard news to lighter fare. The decision to make such a dramatic change in the show's lineup reflects the network's ongoing efforts to revitalize the morning news genre and compete with other top networks like NBC and ABC.
answers: CBS is scrapping its Early Show team, replacing co-hosts Harry Smith and Maggie Rodriguez with the anchors of the show's Saturday edition, Chris Wragge and Erica Hill. Other more minor players also are leaving in the switch, which takes place early next year, the LA Times reports. The show has been consistently stuck in third place, well behind Today and Good Morning America. Smith, who survived the last major overhaul of the show in 2002, will stick with the network as Katie Couric's main backup on the CBS Evening News, notes AP. Click here for more.

pred:
The three news pieces cover the life and legacy of George H.W. Bush, the 41st President of the United States. Here's a brief overview of each passage:

1. "It is my considered judgment that you should now resign. I expect in your lonely, embattled position this would seem to you as an act of disloyalty from one you have supported and helped in so many ways. My own view is that I would now ill serve a president, whose massive accomplishments I will always respect and whose family I love, if I did not now give you my judgment." - This quote from August 1974, when Bush was Republican national chairman, marks the beginning of his resignation from the presidency. The speaker expresses regret for the perceived disloyalty and suggests that Bush may have acted in a manner that could harm the relationship between the president and his supporters.

2. "Five months ago, Saddam Hussein started this cruel war against Kuwait. Tonight, the battle has been joined. ... Our goal is not the conquest of Iraq. It is the liberation of Kuwait." - This statement from January 1991, during the first Gulf War, highlights the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait. Bush emphasizes the importance of liberating Kuwait rather than conquering Iraq, emphasizing the humanitarian aspect of the war and the desire for peace.

3. "Though I might be tempted to utter a few words of encouragement to anyone who is considering my boy, I will heed the immortal words of Dana Carvey: 'Not gonna do it. Wouldn’t be prudent.'" - This quote from early 2000, at a nonpartisan event, serves as a reminder of Bush's commitment to non-partisanship and avoiding involvement in political matters. Despite his son's pursuit of the Republican nomination, Bush remains steadfast in his belief that the focus should remain on issues such as foreign policy, intelligence gathering, and national security.

In summary, these news pieces provide insights into George H.W. Bush's life and presidency, highlighting his leadership roles in the Persian Gulf War, the United Nations, and the Cold War, as well as his commitment to non-partisanship and his role in shaping the policies and actions of the United States. The quotes from his speeches and conversations demonstrate his dedication to serving the country and his willingness to make difficult choices in the face of adversity.
answers: With George HW Bush dead at 94, coverage of the life of the 41st president is plentiful. Here are some early highlights: The broad strokes: For a thorough obituary and assessment, start with the Washington Post. Its story notes that while Bush served just one term as president, it was a consequential one. "The Berlin Wall fell; the Soviet Union ceased to exist; the communist bloc in Eastern Europe broke up; the Cold War ended." And Bush's "firm, restrained diplomatic sense helped assure the harmony and peace with which these world-shaking events played out, one after the other." Great detail: In its obituary, the Wall Street Journal notes that Bush flew 58 missions in the Pacific as a Navy pilot in WWII, all with the name of his girlfriend—Barbara—on the side of the plane. He once got shot down, with this video capturing the rescue. Bush is also the only American besides John Adams to be both president and the father of a president. Read his lips: The Guardian recounts some of his Bush's famous quotes, including his "read my lips" pledge to not raise taxes. He also dissed broccoli.

pred: On Thursday, October 1, 2019, O.J. Simpson, a former NFL star and actor, will appear before the Nevada Parole Board to argue for parole. During his first parole hearing in 2013, Simpson expressed remorse for the armed robbery of memorabilia collectors and stated that he had been a model inmate during his five years in Lovelock. However, in his 2013 parole hearing, Simpson claimed that he had spoken to the victims and apologized for the incident, which he said got out of hand. The Nevada Parole Board will receive updates on Simpson's behavior over the past four years and consider confidential information, including a pre-sentence investigation, a parole hearing report, a risk assessment, and letters of support or opposition. If Simpson is granted parole, he may face challenges from the Brown and Goldman families, who are seeking millions of dollars in damages. The parole hearing is significant because it could potentially impact Simpson's future and determine whether he remains in prison or receives a reduced sentence.
answers: OJ Simpson's parole hearing in Nevada will be broadcast live at 1pm EDT Thursday and there's a strong chance that his path to freedom will be clear by the end of the afternoon. Nobody has registered to testify against the 70-year-old Simpson, who has been in prison for nine years on 12 convictions related to a Las Vegas robbery and will appear before the Nevada Parole Board via videolink, NPR reports. Thursday's hearing will cover four concurrent sentences for use of a deadly weapon and two consecutive sentences for assault with a deadly weapon, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reports. Four board members will vote after the hearing and Simpson could be free by Oct. 1 if they are all in favor of parole. If Simpson is indeed released this fall—which appears almost certainly to be the decision—it will "renew the rabid curiosity" in the case and "produce a spectacle unlike anything we’ve seen since he went behind bars," Nancy Armour at USA Today predicts. There has even been talk that Simpson might end up with a reality TV show, but Armour wants Simpson to avoid the spotlight unless he wants to return to the "toxic mentality that landed him in prison in the first place." If the former NFL star does end up with a TV show, the money is likely to go to the families of murder victims Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, CBS News reports. He will still receive an NFL pension estimated at $25,000 per month.

pred: Jamaica's parliament has passed a bill that decriminalizes the possession of small amounts of marijuana, commonly known as ganja. This historic amendment, which takes effect immediately, removes the criminal charge for possession of up to 2 oz (56.6g) of marijuana, making it a non-arrestable offense. The new law allows the use of marijuana for religious, medical, scientific, and therapeutic purposes, and sets up a licensing agency to regulate the cultivation and distribution of marijuana for these purposes. The legislation also enables the production of industrial hemp, which is a type of marijuana that contains less psychoactive compounds compared to traditional marijuana. The National Security Minister, Peter Bunting, stated that the legislation does not soften Jamaica's stance on transnational drug trafficking or cultivation of illegal plots, but rather aims to address the issue of the drug being used as a recreational substance. The new law has sparked excitement among cannabis enthusiasts and advocates, who see it as a major step towards legalizing the drug for medical and personal use. However, the legislation must be refined in coming months to ensure compliance with international drug conventions and to address concerns about the potential for criminalization of small-scale producers. Overall, the passing of this bill represents a significant shift in Jamaica's approach to drug policy, marking a positive step towards legalizing marijuana for certain uses while addressing the challenges posed by the drug's widespread use and criminalization.
answers: Alaska yesterday became the third state to legalize marijuana for recreational use, and now a country where you would have thought that was the case already is moving closer to that goal itself. Jamaica's parliament last night approved a law decriminalizing small amounts of pot, the AP reports. People found with 2 ounces or less of marijuana will now simply receive a ticket—not a crime on their record—and cultivation of five plants or fewer is now allowed. A licensing agency was also established to oversee pot cultivation and distribution for medical and scientific efforts. Rastafarians are rejoicing, because the bill also grants them the legal right to use cannabis for sacramental purposes, while tourists who have medical marijuana prescriptions elsewhere can pay for permits to buy a bit of ganja on the island. Jamaica has shied away from decriminalization because it didn't want to risk violating international treaties and provoking US sanctions, the Guardian reports. The process for the new law was described by National Security Minister Peter Bunting as an "elephantine," nearly 40-year effort, ABC Australia reports. "[The law] eliminates an unnecessary source of friction between police and citizens, and ensures that our young people are not gratuitously shackled with criminal records," he said in a statement. Jamaica also hopes to boost its health tourism and medical marijuana industries and make it a major player in the pot product market, the Guardian notes. International exporting, however, remains a no-no. A US counternarcotics official told the AP in an email that "Jamaican law is of course Jamaica's own business," but warned that drug trafficking into the US is still illegal.

pred: The search for the wreckage of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed with 162 people on board, has led to the discovery of four large parts of the plane on the sea bed. Indonesian officials have stated that the wreckage was located after sonar equipment detected four massive objects on the ocean floor. The aircraft's main fuselage was identified as the largest object, measuring 18 meters (59 feet) long and 5.4 meters (18 feet) wide. The discovery of the wreckage, particularly if it is largely intact, would greatly benefit the investigation. The Indonesian Navy has been using a ship called the KRI Banda Aceh to assess the dimensions of the objects and determine their potential locations. The search has been ongoing for over a week, with around 30 bodies having been found floating in the choppy waters. The plane's black boxes, which are the flight data and cockpit voice recorders, have not yet been located, but the discovery of the wreckage would provide valuable information for the investigation. Indonesian authorities have suspended AirAsia flights from Surabaya to Singapore, with the Transport Ministry stating that the airline did not have a permit to fly on Sundays. However, Singapore's Civil Aviation Authority has said that from its end, the airline had been approved to fly the route daily. The crash was the airline's first, and strong currents and towering waves have slowed recovery efforts, scattering bodies and debris in all directions. Autopsies will be carried out on some of the bodies, including the pilot and co-pilot, whose remains have not yet been recovered. The hope is that the body of the plane will still be largely intact, speeding the investigation. Vessels involved in the search for debris included at least eight sophisticated navy ships from Singapore, Russia, Malaysia, and the U.S., equipped with sonars for scouring the seabed to pinpoint the all-important black boxes and the wreckage. A second U.S. Navy ship arrived Saturday to help in the search. The search for the wreckage continues, and the Indonesian government is optimistic that the body of the plane will still be largely intact, providing valuable information for the investigation.
answers: Search teams in Indonesia may have found the main fuselage of the AirAsia plane where most of the remaining victims and the plane's black boxes are expected to be. Authorities found "four big parts of the plane we're looking for," says the official in charge of the search in the Java Sea, reports Reuters. The biggest of the pieces is about 59 feet long and 18 feet wide, reports AP. The pieces have only been detected, not recovered, and divers hope conditions will permit them to reach the objects tomorrow. So far, only 30 of 162 bodies have been recovered, and most of the victims are believed to be still strapped in their seats. Authorities also said today that AirAsia was in violation of its license by flying to Singapore on a Sunday, the day of the crash, reports the Telegraph. As a result, the airline might have its license revoked in Indonesia. There's still no conclusions yet in what caused the crash, but theories continue to center on stormy conditions. "Flight 8501 appears to have been trapped in bad weather that would have been difficult to avoid," says a report by Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency.

pred:
The Internet Archive is undertaking a project called "Crawls for History," which involves archiving pages as they are created and preserving the pages that they reference. This initiative aims to address the issue of broken links on the web, which can lead to users being unable to access content or experiencing a "404" error. The goal is to replace broken links with archived versions of the original pages, ensuring that users have access to the information they were intended to find.

The Internet Archive has identified a list of "No More 404" sites, which are websites that have been removed or significantly altered since their creation. These sites are considered important historical resources and serve as a starting point for researchers, educators, and enthusiasts who want to explore and learn about past events or cultural phenomena.

To achieve this objective, the Internet Archive is conducting regular crawls of these No More 404 sites. During each crawl, the archive captures the current state of the site, including its structure, content, and any changes made since the last crawl. The captured data is then stored in a database, along with metadata such as the date of the last update, the URL of the original page, and any relevant author information.

Once the data is collected, the Internet Archive uses various techniques to identify and preserve the archived versions of the No More 404 sites. One approach is to use machine learning algorithms to analyze the structure and content of the crawled pages, looking for patterns and relationships between them. This helps the archive to understand how the original pages were structured and how they relate to other pages on the web.

Another method used by the Internet Archive is to create companion links for the archived pages. These links provide users with a direct connection to the original page, allowing them to navigate back to it if they need to revisit the information. Companion links also help to maintain the integrity of the original website by providing a consistent experience across different devices and browsers.

In addition to preserving the original pages, the Internet Archive is also working to ensure that the archived versions are accessible to a wide range of users. To do this, the archive provides tools and resources for users to search and browse the archives, including a search engine that allows users to filter and sort the results based on various criteria, such as date, author, or topic.

Overall, the "Crawls for History" project is a significant step towards addressing the problem of broken links on the web and preserving valuable historical resources for future generations. By archiving and preserving the pages that are
answers: The Telegraph reported yesterday on a crazy court case in the UK: After a pregnant Italian woman, in town for business, had a panic attack, social service workers in Essex got a court order allowing the woman to be forcibly sedated and undergo a C-section so they could take her baby. Fifteen months later, the little girl is still with social service workers, who won't return her to her mother. The case is now "an international legal row," the Telegraph says, and the anonymous woman's lawyers call it "unprecedented." The woman was in Britain in July 2012 for an airline training course, and called police when she suffered the panic attack. They arrived while she was on the phone with her mother, who told police the woman suffered from bipolar disorder and was off her medication, according to a Telegraph columnist. Police took her to a psychiatric facility, and restrained her under the Mental Health Act when she said she wanted to go back to her hotel. She underwent the C-section after having been there five weeks. The case is ongoing; the mother says she has made a full recovery, but a judge nonetheless ruled that her daughter should be put up for adoption. More on the case here and here.

pred: The passage discusses the importance of habeas corpus, a legal procedure that prevents governments from holding individuals indefinitely without sufficient cause. The habeas corpus petition is a crucial tool for challenging detention and ensuring due process. The United States Constitution enshrines habeas corpus as a cornerstone of the legal system, protecting citizens' liberty, justice, and democracy. The MCA, a law passed in 2006, has reversed the right to habeas corpus for anyone detained at Guantánamo Bay and for any foreigner the government detains anywhere and labels an "enemy combatant." The MCA applies to legal residents of the US, including those who have lived in the US for years, potentially leading to the labeling of an individual as an "enemy combatant" and imprisonment without legal recourse. The Supreme Court recently ruled that the habeas corpus petition of Hercules and Leo, two research chimpanzees at Stony Brook University, should be allowed to proceed, marking the first time in U.S. history that an animal has been covered by a writ of habeas corpus. The court hearing is scheduled for May 27, where the judge will hear legal arguments regarding whether Hercules and Leo should remain at Stony Brook. The case has sparked controversy and raised questions about the treatment of animals in captivity and the limits of the executive branch's authority. The Nonhuman Rights Project, a nonprofit organization, has filed a similar habeas corpus petition for chimpanzees at Stony Brook, arguing that they are too cognitively and emotionally complex to be held in captivity and should be relocated to an established chimpanzee sanctuary. The case has been appealed multiple times, but the latest ruling by New York Supreme Court Justice Barbara Jaffe grants a representative of Stony Brook University to appear in court on May 6 to respond to NhRP's petition. The group plans to file another case involving a captive elephant by the end of the year and has set its sights on other animals, including research animals, across the country. The passage highlights the ongoing struggle to protect the rights of animals and ensure due process in the face of increasing encroachment on their autonomy and bodily liberty.
answers: The writ of habeas corpus lets prisoners appear in court to make their captors justify why they're being held. Until now in the US, those who've used this legal tactic have been human. But a New York judge yesterday ruled that the writ may be used by two lab chimpanzees at Stony Brook University, Science magazine reports. NY Supreme Court Justice Barbara Jaffe ordered a university rep to address a suit filed by the Nonhuman Rights Project by appearing in court May 6 to argue why the college is holding Hercules and Leo. The group, which says the animals are being detained for biomedical experiments, says its ultimate goal is to have the animals released to the Save the Chimps sanctuary in Fort Pierce, Fla., per the NhRP's website. "This is a big step forward to getting what we are ultimately seeking: the right to bodily liberty for chimpanzees and other cognitively complex animals," Natalie Prosin, the project's executive director, tells Science. The case kicked off in December 2013 with lawsuits that also included two chimps held on private property; each case was struck down, sending the NhRP down the appeals path. Not everyone's convinced the upcoming hearing will mean liberation for the chimps. A Pepperdine University law professor tells Science that the judge likely just wants to hear both sides of the story: "It would be quite surprising if the judge intended to make a momentous substantive finding that chimpanzees are legal persons" without doing so, he notes. Prosin, meanwhile, says her group isn't stopping with the chimps and will also target the release of other animals. (Click to read about what chimps talk to each other about.)

pred: On February 21, 2013, a deadly car crash occurred on the Las Vegas Strip, resulting in the deaths of three individuals and injuries to at least six others. The incident began with a dispute between two vehicles, a black Range Rover SUV and a white Maserati, driven by a black Range Rover driver named Kenneth Wayne Cherry Jr. Cherry was driving the Range Rover when he opened fire on the Maserati, causing it to crash into a taxi cab that burst into flames. The driver and passenger of the taxi were killed, and the Range Rover driver was pronounced dead at a hospital. The SUV then raced off and was pursued by law enforcement, who contacted authorities in three states to track down the vehicle. The SUV was later found abandoned in a remote location, with tinted windows, black tire rims, and paper dealer plates from out of state. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear, but it appears to have been triggered by a disagreement between the Range Rover driver and another driver in the valet area of the Aria resort. The incident was the latest violence on the Las Vegas Strip since the beginning of the year, with two people being critically wounded in a shooting at a parking garage on February 6 and a tourist being stabbed in an elevator at The Hotel at Mandalay Bay. The police have video footage from traffic cameras at the intersection and are checking hotel surveillance systems to identify any potential suspects. The incident has raised concerns about safety on the Strip, with the closure of several major hotels and the detaining of citizens at immigration officials' request. The Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority has assured visitors that the Strip is safe and that the police are taking steps to prevent future incidents. The incident has also led to increased scrutiny of the city's approach to crime prevention and public safety, with some residents expressing concern about the lack of resources and support for victims of violence.
answers: Police in three states are still hunting for a Range Rover whose occupants opened fire on another car on the Vegas Strip this morning and set off a deadly chain reaction. Cops don't know most of the details, but they say it started with a dispute of some kind in one of the nearby hotels, then spilled into the street, reports the Las Vegas Sun. When the Range Rover caught up to a Maserati at a stop light, shots were fired from the SUV that sent the Maserati crashing into a taxi, which exploded upon impact. Three people—the Maserati driver, the taxi driver, and a taxi passenger—were killed, and three others were injured, reports the LA Times. Police are hoping to piece together more details by interviewing a passenger in the Maserati, who was injured in the melee. Earlier reports that gunfire came from both vehicles as part of a moving shootout were incorrect. The AP collects this quote from a tourist visiting from Manchester, England: "This doesn't happen where we come from, not on this scale. We get stabbings, and gang violence, but this is like something out of a movie. Like Die Hard or something."

pred: The story revolves around a teenager named Autumn Veatch, who survived a small-plane crash in the North Cascades, Washington state. She managed to survive for two days in rugged terrain before being found and taken to an Okanogan County hospital with minor injuries. Her parents, David Veatch and his wife Misty, were also on board the plane, but their fate remains unknown. Autumn's survival was attributed to her quick thinking and resourcefulness, as she followed a trail to state Route 20, near the east entrance to North Cascades National Park, and eventually found a trail and followed it to the trailhead on Highway 20. She was picked up by a motorist who took her to a general store in Mazama, where employees called 911. The Aero Methow Rescue Service sent a paramedic team to check her out before she was taken to a hospital in Brewster for treatment of what appeared to be minor injuries. The police and rescue teams searched the mountains for the plane, aided by Autumn's description of the crash site, but there was no sign of the aircraft or its occupants until she was found hiking down the trail. The crashed plane crossed the Idaho-Washington border about 2:20 p.m. PDT Saturday, but it dropped off the radar near Omak, Washington, about an hour later, transportation officials said. The last phone signal from one of the plane's occupants was detected around 3:50 p.m. The story highlights the importance of preparedness and resourcefulness in the face of emergencies, especially in remote and rugged environments like the North Cascades. The incident serves as a reminder of the potential dangers of air travel and the need for proper planning and preparation for such situations.
answers: A 16-year-old girl in Washington state is bruised and dehydrated but very much alive after surviving a plane crash and a long trek through what authorities describe as some of the state's most rugged terrain. Autumn Veatch was on a small plane with her step-grandparents that crashed after departing Kalispell, Mont., on Saturday afternoon, the Bellingham Herald reports. There was no sign of the plane or its occupants until a motorist found Veatch on State Route 20 yesterday afternoon and took her to a general store, where employees called authorities, the AP reports. She was hospitalized with minor injuries. Her father tells the Herald that after the plane crashed into a mountain, it caught fire and she was unable to get her step-grandparents out. She spent about a day near the plane waiting for rescue before following a stream and then a trail out of the woods, her father says. Friends say both father and daughter are completely overwhelmed. "She did joke that it was a good thing she'd watched all those Survivor shows that she didn't like, but her dad made her watch anyway," a family friend tells the Seattle Times. Authorities are still searching for the missing Beech A-35. (In Colombia last month, a mother and baby survived four days in the jungle after a plane crash.)

pred: The United States Justice Department has announced that it will file criminal charges against Gibson Guitar Corporation, a popular manufacturer of musical instruments, for trafficking in illegally obtained wood. The company was accused of importing ebony and rosewood from Madagascar, which were both protected under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) in the United States. The Lacey Act, which was amended in 2008 to include plants, was cited as the basis for the charges. pred: The three news articles discuss the discovery of an ancient ocean on Mars, which is estimated to have covered a significant portion of the planet's surface four billion years ago. The ocean was enriched in deuterium, a heavy isotope of hydrogen, to a level of seven times that of Earth's ocean, indicating a large-scale water loss. The study, conducted by a team of scientists led by Geronimo Villanueva, used infrared telescopes to map the Martian atmosphere over six years and analyzed the chemical composition of the vapor present in the atmosphere. The data showed that the ordinary hydrogen in water on Mars has been slowly leaking into outer space, leading to a higher proportion of deuterium in the water compared to Earth. The team calculated that the amount of water needed to cover the entire planet evenly would have reached a depth of about 450 feet (137 meters), but in reality, it may have formed an ocean in the northern hemisphere, with a consistently lower altitude. The findings suggest that Mars was once much wetter and warmer than it is today, with much of the water being in liquid form rather than in the icy polar caps where it is currently locked up. The study provides evidence for the existence of an ancient ocean on Mars, which could potentially support the possibility of life on the planet. However, the authors caution that the true amount of water on Mars is likely much larger due to the escape of heavy hydrogen from the atmosphere. The search for life on Mars will continue in 2018 when the European Space Agency sends its Exomars rover to the red planet, which will aim to detect chemical signatures of life, possibly emanating from microbial life deep beneath the Martian soil. The study highlights the importance of understanding the chemical composition of the Martian atmosphere and the potential for life to exist on the planet, despite the challenges posed by the thin atmosphere and the lack of evidence for life on Mars.
answers: Imagine all the water in the Arctic Ocean. Now, imagine all that and more on Mars. If you visited the Red Planet roughly 4.3 billion years ago, that's what you likely would have found, say NASA scientists. Their new study arrived at that "solid estimate ... by determining how much water was lost to space," says lead author Geronimo Villanueva. The Guardian reports the scientists used three powerful infrared telescopes to analyze two forms of water in Mars' atmosphere: H2O and HDO, in which deuterium (aka "heavy" hydrogen) has taken the place of one hydrogen atom. As National Geographic explains, Mars' gravity is weaker than our own; that allowed hydrogen to escape from the atmosphere and into space over time, boosting the amount of deuterium in its water. Scientists compared the ratio of HDO to H2O in Martian water today with that in water from a 4.5 billion-year-old Mars meteorite to arrive at their conclusions, a press release states. They ultimately calculated that Mars was once home to 20 million cubic kilometers of ocean. It could have covered every inch of the planet in water 450 feet deep, but the scientists think a different scenario is more likely: that the ocean covered roughly a fifth of the planet, was located in the northern hemisphere, and was as much as a mile deep. While National Geographic observes the findings back up "reams of earlier evidence that water once existed on the surface" of Mars, another study author points out the assessment of the degree of water lost indicates something new. "The planet was very likely wet for a longer period of time than was previously thought, suggesting it might have been habitable for longer," a scientist says. (Mysterious plumes on Mars are stumping scientists.)

pred: The European Court of Justice has ruled that Nestlé, the maker of Kit Kat, does not own the shape of the four-fingered wafer biscuits, despite arguing that it owns the trademark for the same shape. The court found that Mondelez, the American competitor, had validly registered the shape as a trademark in the EU, and that Nestlé's appeal was invalid. The ruling follows a long-standing legal battle between Nestlé and Mondelez over the shape of the four-fingered wafer biscuits, which has been ongoing since 2002. The case was initially brought by Nestlé in 2002, seeking to protect the shape as an EU trademark, but the lower EU court ruled in 2016 that Nestlé did not have sufficient evidence to prove that consumers in every EU country recognized the shape as distinctive. However, the Luxembourg court overturned that decision in 2018, finding that Nestlé had failed to show that consumers in enough EU countries recognized the shape as distinctive. The ruling has implications for chocolate brands operating across the EU single market, where there are varying histories in national markets. The case has also been mirrored by a dispute between the two multinationals in the British courts, where Nestle objected to a trademark for the purple color used by Cadbury, bought by the Americans in 2010, to wrap its Dairy Milk chocolate bars. The ruling means that Kit Kat will lose its EU trademark, but it leaves open the possibility of future challenges to protect the shape in other EU countries.
answers: "Four trapezoidal bars aligned on a rectangular base" may not be instantly recognizable. pred: The study published in the journal Evolution investigates the evolution of closed-mouth vocalizations in birds and other reptilian groups. The researchers analyzed the distribution of closed-mouth vocalizations in birds and compared it to the sounds produced by other reptilian groups, such as crocodiles and birds. They found that the ability to produce closed-mouth vocalizations evolved at least 16 times in archosaurs, a group that includes birds, dinosaurs, and crocodiles. The researchers also noted that only animals with a relatively large body size (such as doves or larger) use this behavior. The study suggests that closed-mouth vocalization emerged in diverse archosaur species based on behavioral or environmental circumstances, and it may have been used in mating displays similar to birds. However, no direct fossil evidence exists to reveal what dinosaurs sounded like. The study offers clues about how living birds vocalize and highlights the importance of understanding the sounds that extinct early avian species, and perhaps their dinosaur ancestors, produced.
answers: Dinosaurs may have been much more like modern birds than we knew—and not just because some had feathers. A new study suggests that mighty dinosaurs of yore didn't roar, contrary to every dinosaur movie you've ever seen. Instead, they made a decidedly less scary sound called a "closed-mouth vocalization." Think of a dove cooing or perhaps an ostrich doing this grunting thing. As the scientists explain in the journal Evolution, per UT News, the sound actually comes out of the neck area after air is pushed through an esophageal pouch. In fact, the animal's mouth is shut the whole time. Lots of birds do this today, and because birds descended from dinosaurs, scientists suspect they may have communicated in a similar way. The fossil record can't prove it, though the Washington Post notes that previous research meshes with the idea, including the belief that dinosaurs had air sacs instead of vocal chords. “A cool thing about this work is the demonstration that closed-mouth behavior evolved many times,” says the lead author. “That suggests it can emerge fairly easily and be incorporated into mating displays" among different types of animals. A co-author says the study gives the impression of "a very different Jurassic world. Not only were dinosaurs feathered, but they may have had bulging necks and made booming, closed-mouth sounds." But if so, the makers of Jurassic Park didn't get it all wrong: The hiss of the film's velociraptors came from a goose, per Vulture. (Scientists have grown chickens with dinosaur legs.)

answers: A classy move by a Florida cop is making headlines: Laurie Graber, an officer in Plantation, got the call for a particularly low-level crime—someone had ripped the engagement ring off the finger of an 87-year-old woman bedridden with Alzheimer's in a hospital, reports Fox News. answers: InterContinentalExchange Inc. has agreed to buy NYSE Euronext, the company that owns the New York Stock Exchange, for $8.2 billion, the two companies announced this morning. Researchers from UC Berkeley, led by Professor Jack Gallant, have developed a computer model that reconstructs YouTube videos from viewers' brain activity. The model matches features of the videos, such as colors, shapes, and movements, with patterns of brain activity recorded during the viewing process. By analyzing subtle changes in blood flow to visual areas of the brain, the researchers were able to predict what was on the screen at the time, including scenes from movies that were not directly visible to the naked eye.

The study has implications for a variety of fields, including neuroscience, psychology, and artificial intelligence. It opens up the possibility of decoding inner images and understanding how the brain processes visual experiences, potentially leading to breakthroughs in diagnosing mental health disorders, enhancing virtual reality experiences, and even assisting individuals with paralysis by controlling their environment through imagined sequences of movements.

However, the technology's limitations lie in its accuracy and the nature of the abstract visual experiences it captures. While the reconstructed videos provide a glimpse into the movies in the mind, they lack the context and realism of real-world visual experiences. Moreover, the brain activity measured in this study is just a fraction of the activity that allows us to see moving images, highlighting the complexity of the visual system and the need for further research to fully understand how the brain processes both naturalistic and abstract visual experiences.

The potential applications of this technology extend beyond entertainment, with the researchers suggesting that it could be used to broadcast imagery, such as scenes from dreams or memories, providing insights into the subconscious mind. However, the feasibility of using this technology to watch people's dreams or memories remains uncertain, as the technology currently lacks the resolution required for accurate interpretations.

In conclusion, the development of a computer model that reconstructs YouTube videos from brain activity represents a significant advancement in our understanding of the brain's capacity for visual processing. While the technology holds promise for various applications, including diagnosis, visualization, and assistive technologies, it is crucial to address the limitations and challenges associated with its accuracy and the nature of the abstract visual experiences it captures. Further research is needed to fully explore the potential of this technology in revolutionizing various fields and improving human cognition.
answers: Scientists at UC Berkeley have made a major advancement in the field of mind reading, reconstructing YouTube videos based on brain scans from people who’d seen them. Researchers would put subjects into an MRI machine and track their brain activity as they viewed videos. Once they’d build a model of how a subject’s mind processed the video, “we could read brain activity for that subject and run it backward … to try to uncover what the viewer saw,” one study coauthor tells ABC News. Using the scans they were then able to reproduce the videos—though they’re blurry. “This is a major leap,” the co-author says. He thinks the technique could eventually be used to reconstruct dreams or memories, if it turns out the brain processes those things similarly to how it processes movies. “It’s our next line of research.” (More details on how the experiment worked, along with a video, at PC Magazine.)

answers: Forget satellite images and aerial searches—the best way to find Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may be with mathematical techniques dating back to the 18th century, the BBC reports. That's how Air France flight 447 was found in 2009, using "Bayesian statistics" to measure the probability of the plane being in one place or another. Named after Presbyterian minister and mathematician Thomas Bayes, the technique allowed experts to apply several factors to each point on a map: For example, what was the chance it crashed from mechanical failure? How far do planes tend to crash from their last known location? What was the chance that search teams missed debris in various locations? It's like picking a restaurant by balancing how full it is, what your favorite restaurant-review website says, and so on—except that experts hunting for Airbus A330 did that for each point where plane may have crashed in the Atlantic, Five Thirty-Eight notes. It was so hard that the US team of statisticians invited by France gave up, until they de-emphasized one statistic: that a plane's black box emits a signal after a crash 90% of the time. They changed their findings, and presto, the plane was found. Bayesian techniques have helped people find World War II U-boats, men overboard, and sunken treasure, but there's no evidence that Malaysia is employing them now. "I suspect that they just guess, like professional baseball managers used to do before Moneyball," says a biostatistician.

pred: The three consecutive supermoons of December 31, 2017, January 1, and January 31, 2018, have been observed by astronomers around the world. These supermoons are known as "blood moons," as they appear larger and brighter than regular full moons due to the bending of light caused by the Earth's atmosphere. The first supermoon occurred when the moon was 26,500 kilometers away from Earth, and it will reappear as a visible supermoon on New Year's Day 2018. The second full moon of the month, the Jan. 31 supermoon, will also feature a total lunar eclipse, with totality visible from eastern Asia across the Pacific to western North America. The eclipse will begin at 11:48 am UTC and reach its maximum at 1:30 pm UTC, with viewers needing to wake up early to catch the partial eclipse. The best time to enjoy both supermoon and lunar eclipse is right after moonrise and before sunrise, when the moon is sitting on the horizon. The Virtual Telescope Project provides a livestream of the Jan. 1 supermoon rise over Rome's skyline, beginning at 4:00 pm UTC, and the Jan. 31 eclipse from Australia, beginning at 11:30 am UTC. Photography tips include tapping on the moon on the screen and holding your finger in place to lock the camera's focus, adjusting the exposure slider, and using the daylight white balance to adjust for the sunlight being reflected off the moon. Special glasses are not necessary to view the supermoon or lunar eclipse safely.
answers: Look up at the sky on Jan. 31 and you may witness a sight unseen for 150 years. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)

The article discusses the global obesity crisis, which affects millions of people worldwide, accounting for approximately 2.1 billion people, or 13% of the world's population. The study, conducted by the University of Washington-Seattle's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, provides the most comprehensive analysis of obesity trends over the past few decades, revealing that obesity rates have risen significantly across various countries, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa, Central America, and the Pacific and Caribbean islands. The study highlights the following key findings:

1. Obesity prevalence: The number of overweight or obese individuals worldwide increased from 857 million in 1980 to 2.1 billion in 2013, representing a 30% increase in the global population.
2. Distribution of obesity: Obesity is more prevalent in developed countries than in poorer nations, with the highest rates occurring in the Middle East and North Africa, followed by Central America, the Pacific, and Caribbean islands.
3. Economic factors contributing to obesity: The availability of cheap, fatty, sugary, salty, high-calorie "junk food" and sedentary lifestyles are significant contributors to obesity, particularly in developing countries where access to these foods and opportunities for physical activity are limited.
4. Rising obesity rates in younger populations: Obesity rates have increased nearly 50% in children and adolescents worldwide, with men showing higher rates in developed countries compared to women in developing countries.
5. Impact on health: Obesity is associated with numerous chronic complications, such as heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers, leading to an estimated 3.4 million deaths annually.
6. Global burden of obesity: Obesity is a major risk factor for morbidity and mortality, affecting over two-thirds of the world's obese population, primarily residing in developing countries.
7. Challenges in addressing obesity: Despite progress in reducing obesity rates in some developed countries, no country has successfully cut its obesity rate, highlighting the need for a multifaceted approach to tackle this complex public health issue.

The study emphasizes the importance of addressing obesity through a combination of lifestyle modifications, dietary interventions, and policy measures, particularly in developing countries where access to healthy food options and opportunities for physical activity are limited. The World Health Organization has launched a commission to study rising obesity among children worldwide and propose solutions, aiming to reduce the global obesity burden and improve public health outcomes.
answers: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. The 188-country study found that there are 2.1 billion overweight or obese people in the world, making up around 30% of the world's population, up from 20% in 1980, USA Today reports. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." The study published in British medical journal the Lancet found that the Middle East and north Africa had seen the biggest weight gains, though the US still has the largest number of obese people, with 87 million of the world's 671 million obese people, reports Reuters. Other countries, however, have even higher obesity rates, including Tonga, where more than 50% of all adults are obese. "Two-thirds of the obese population actually resides in developing countries," says one of the researchers; they warn that obesity rates are rising among rich and poor countries, men and women, and adults and children alike.

answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.

pred: A Toyota Corolla driven by Nabila Altahan in Mendon, Massachusetts, was suspended from a telephone pole due to a GPS system's sudden directions to turn around. The driver, Altahan, reacted too quickly to the instructions, causing the car to leave the lane of traffic and end up suspended on the guy wire. A witness at the nearby mini-golf course reported seeing the driver jump out of the car as it was suspended from the pole. The incident occurred around 8 p.m. on Wednesday evening, and no injuries were reported. State Police responded to the scene along with Rutland City Fire Department. The cause of the incident is still under investigation, but it appears that the driver may have been following the GPS system's directions without fully understanding their implications.
answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
